The Support Our Military Working Dogs Act ensures that our nation’s military dogs receive the best possible care and a path to their forever home once they retire from service.

https://t.co/f0PzjeLuRo

Military dogs serve on the front lines with our troops to defend our nation and provide recuperating services for our veterans and their former handlers. Caring for these dogs in the field and once they return home is a major concern that must be addressed.

This bill would authorize better veterinary care for retired military dogs and direct the U.S. Department of Defense to work with veterans’ service organizations and other nonprofits to support their long-term care, once adopted by their former handler’s into loving homes.
Today .@RepAndyKimNJ and I introduced the “Support Our Military Working Dogs Act” (H.R.6188) in commemoration of National K9 Veterans Day.

I thank the American Shipbuilding Suppliers Association for this award. https://t.co/bLAutkfv1H

If enacted, the bill is expected to spur the construction of dozens of ships, supporting thousands of good-paying jobs in American shipyards, as well as the domestic vessel component manufacturing and maritime industries.

Last year, Senator Wicker and I reintroduced the “Energizing American Shipbuilding Act,” which would require that vessels built in the United States transport 15 percent of total seaborne LNG exports by 2041 and 10 percent of total seaborne crude oil exports by 2033.

I was honored to receive the Thad Cochran Leadership Award from the American Shipbuilding Suppliers Association this week. Supporting our nation’s shipbuilding and maritime industries is one of my priorities in Congress.

I have been fighting for this legislation since 2015 after major crude-by-rail derailments that cost lives in the United States and Canada. In 2013, the tragic derailment in Lac-Megantic, Quebec killed 47 people.
My bill simply requires oil companies to decrease the volatility to market levels, rather than carrying unstable products through places like Marysville, Davis, and Dixon.

Recently, I introduced the “Crude by Rail Volatility Standard Act” (H.R.5553). This legislation would protect our communities from the major safety risk that’s posed by transporting combustible Bakken crude oil-by-rail through communities like Davis and Marysville.
